articles.headline: How to Gauge a C.E.O.’s Value? Hint: It’s Not the Share Price
articles.snippet: A company’s stock can rocket even as its operations are being run into the ground. But how else to link a chief’s pay to performance?
articles.abstract: A company’s stock can rocket even as its operations are being run into the ground. But how else to link a chief’s pay to performance?
articles.lead_paragraph: Everybody knows that chief executives receive bounteous pay as a matter of course. In 2015, for example, the median pay for a top corporate executive at 200 large American companies was $19.3 million.

articles.headline: Moving to Arizona Soon? You Might Need a License
articles.snippet: States are adding more licensing requirements for a variety of jobs, mandating months or years of education, along with assessing costly fees.
articles.abstract: States are adding more licensing requirements for a variety of jobs, mandating months or years of education, along with assessing costly fees.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — “I usually start behind the neck,” Grace Granatelli said from her plump brown sofa. “There’s two pressure points back behind the ears that help relax them a little bit.” In her lap, she held the head of Sketch, her mixed beagle rat terrier, as her fingers traced small circles through his fur.

articles.headline: Britain Asks if Tone of ‘Brexit’ Campaign Made Violence Inevitable
articles.snippet: The killing of Jo Cox, a politician in favor of remaining in the European Union, has put a focus on the anti-immigrant tactics some in the “Leave” campaign have employed.
articles.abstract: The killing of Jo Cox, a politician in favor of remaining in the European Union, has put a focus on the anti-immigrant tactics some in the “Leave” campaign have employed.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the shock of the brutal murder  of a young member of Parliament began to subside on Friday, there was a growing sense in Britain that something ominous had been unleashed in the country.

articles.headline: Costly Compromises Stir Fury With the European Union
articles.snippet: Many Britons want to stop paying for an unwieldy club often hobbled by a lack of consensus.
articles.abstract: Many Britons want to stop paying for an unwieldy club often hobbled by a lack of consensus.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — To the sort of dysfunction that provokes frustration with the European Union, add its highest appeals court.

articles.headline: A Saudi Imam, 2 Hijackers and Lingering 9/11 Mystery
articles.snippet: To some, a classified section of an inquiry into the terrorist attacks points to Saudi involvement, while the country’s foreign minister says, “There is no there there.”
articles.abstract: To some, a classified section of an inquiry into the terrorist attacks points to Saudi involvement, while the country’s foreign minister says, “There is no there there.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Inside an opulent palace in Riyadh late one evening in February 2004, two American investigators interrogated a man they believed might hold answers to one of the lingering mysteries of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks: What role, if any, did officials in Saudi Arabia’s government play in the plot?
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane

articles.headline: IEX Group, Critical of Wall St., Gains Approval for Stock Exchange
articles.snippet: After a brutal lobbying battle, and months of delays, America is getting a new stock exchange from the most prominent high-profile critics of high-frequency trading.
articles.abstract: After a brutal lobbying battle, and months of delays, America is getting a new stock exchange from the most prominent high-profile critics of high-frequency trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: America is getting a new stock exchange from the most prominent critics of high-frequency trading.

articles.headline: After 147 Years, Goldman Sachs Hangs a Shingle on Main Street
articles.snippet: The elite Wall Street institution now sees growth opportunities in catering to the everyday people it has avoided through its history.
articles.abstract: The elite Wall Street institution now sees growth opportunities in catering to the everyday people it has avoided through its history.
articles.lead_paragraph: You used to need $10 million to become a customer of Goldman Sachs.

articles.headline: Words of Obama’s Father Still Waiting to Be Read by His Son
articles.snippet: Letters written long ago by Barack Obama Sr. shed new light on a young Kenyan whose ambitions helped change the course of U.S. history. But for the president, they may also revive old pain.
articles.abstract: Letters written long ago by Barack Obama Sr. shed new light on a young Kenyan whose ambitions helped change the course of U.S. history. But for the president, they may also revive old pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: The archivist stumbled across the file in a stack of boxes on the second floor of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem. The yellowing letters inside dated back more than half a century, chronicling the dreams and struggles of a young man in Kenya.

articles.headline: ‘Always Agitated. Always Mad’: Omar Mateen, According to Those Who Knew Him
articles.snippet: The recollections of those who knew Omar Mateen or encountered him conjure a man forever aggrieved; forever not at peace; forever out of step.
articles.abstract: The recollections of those who knew Omar Mateen or encountered him conjure a man forever aggrieved; forever not at peace; forever out of step.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — The brother of the bride arrived late for her reception. But soon enough he was mingling at the lakeside pavilion in West Palm Beach, where a diverse gathering of guests dined on chicken tikka masala and goat biryani while admiring the view of the Intracoastal Waterway just beyond the floor-to-ceiling windows.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry, Serge F. Kovaleski, Alan Blinder and Mujib Mashal

articles.headline: Many What-Ifs in Donald Trump’s Plan for Migrants
articles.snippet: Immigration experts agree that while the president has the power to order a ban, it would prompt retaliation against American citizens abroad.
articles.abstract: Immigration experts agree that while the president has the power to order a ban, it would prompt retaliation against American citizens abroad.
articles.lead_paragraph: In an address after the Orlando massacre punctuated with dire warnings of impending violence, Donald J. Trump said he would “suspend immigration from areas of the world when there is a proven history of terrorism” against the United States or its allies. Mr. Trump promised fixes to the immigration system that would be “tough” and “smart” and “fast.”

articles.headline: Regardless of ‘Brexit’ Vote, Experts Say, E.U. Must Rethink Status Quo
articles.snippet: Tribulations for the euro, a debt standoff with Greece and a flawed approach to migration all inflamed the angry nationalism spreading across the Continent and Britain.
articles.abstract: Tribulations for the euro, a debt standoff with Greece and a flawed approach to migration all inflamed the angry nationalism spreading across the Continent and Britain.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — Among the well-heeled bureaucrats of the European Union, it is an article of faith that the bloc always emerges stronger from a crisis. The idealistic founders who six decades ago dreamed of stitching warring nations into a peaceful whole knew the path would be bumpy. But always, the union wobbled forward.

articles.headline: A War of Brothers in Iraq: ‘I Will Kill Him With My Own Hands’
articles.snippet: For Iraqi Sunnis, the struggle to retake Falluja from the Islamic State underscores the personal nature of war: a conflict of sons and brothers, nephews and neighbors.
articles.abstract: For Iraqi Sunnis, the struggle to retake Falluja from the Islamic State underscores the personal nature of war: a conflict of sons and brothers, nephews and neighbors.
articles.lead_paragraph: FALLUJA, Iraq — In the days leading up to the storming of Falluja by Iraqi forces, Brig. Gen. Hadi Razaij, the leading Sunni police commander in the campaign, sat on a cot in an abandoned house near the front line. He described the resistance that lay ahead: a determined force of hundreds of jihadists that had months to prepare.
articles.byline: By Tim Arango and Falih Hassan

articles.headline: Decades Later, Sickness Among Airmen After a Hydrogen Bomb Accident
articles.snippet: The Air Force says that there was no harmful radiation at the crash site in Spain, but interviews with dozens of men and details from declassified documents disagree.
articles.abstract: The Air Force says that there was no harmful radiation at the crash site in Spain, but interviews with dozens of men and details from declassified documents disagree.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alarms sounded on United States Air Force bases in Spain and officers began packing all the low-ranking troops they could grab onto buses for a secret mission. There were cooks, grocery clerks and even musicians from the Air Force band.

articles.headline: Airbnb Vows to Fight Racism, but Its Users Can’t Sue to Prompt Fairness
articles.snippet: Airbnb tells users they must agree to waive the right to sue, or to join in any class-action lawsuit or class-action arbitration, as a condition of using the service.
articles.abstract: Airbnb tells users they must agree to waive the right to sue, or to join in any class-action lawsuit or class-action arbitration, as a condition of using the service.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Brian Chesky, chief executive of Airbnb, made a vow this month to root out bigotry from his business.

articles.headline: Venezuelans Ransack Stores as Hunger Grips the Nation
articles.snippet: A nation anxiously searches for ways to feed itself, as the economic collapse of recent years has left it unable to produce or import sufficient food.
articles.abstract: A nation anxiously searches for ways to feed itself, as the economic collapse of recent years has left it unable to produce or import sufficient food.
articles.lead_paragraph: CUMANÁ, Venezuela — With delivery trucks under constant attack, the nation’s food is now transported under armed guard. Soldiers stand watch over bakeries. The police fire rubber bullets at desperate mobs storming grocery stores, pharmacies and butcher shops. A 4-year-old girl was shot to death as street gangs fought over food.

articles.headline: How Should Hillary Clinton Choose a Running Mate? Start With Chemistry
articles.snippet: The Clinton campaign is searching for a charismatic Democrat who can click with, but not outshine, its candidate. Auditions have already started.
articles.abstract: The Clinton campaign is searching for a charismatic Democrat who can click with, but not outshine, its candidate. Auditions have already started.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a college gymnasium this month in Newark, Senator Cory A. Booker introduced Hillary Clinton to the crowd.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Health Insurer Hoped to Disrupt the Industry, but Struggles in State Marketplaces
articles.snippet: Oscar Health attracted venture capitalists to its technology-oriented effort, but the market is smaller than it and other start-up insurers hoped.
articles.abstract: Oscar Health attracted venture capitalists to its technology-oriented effort, but the market is smaller than it and other start-up insurers hoped.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oscar Health was going to be a new kind of insurance company. Started in 2012, just in time to offer plans to people buying insurance under the new federal health care law, the business promised to use technology to push less costly care and more consumer-friendly coverage.

articles.headline: Europe’s Emergency Workers Turn to Drones to Save Lives
articles.snippet: A six-month training program for teams from Britain, Denmark, Iceland and Ireland aims to test the use of unmanned aircraft in emergencies.
articles.abstract: A six-month training program for teams from Britain, Denmark, Iceland and Ireland aims to test the use of unmanned aircraft in emergencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: COPENHAGEN — In a deserted grassy field on the outskirts of the Danish capital, Steve McLinden was struggling to land his drone as it teetered 200 feet above and barely in sight, battling winds of almost 10 miles an hour.

articles.headline: Reckoning Near for Merger of Energy Transfer and Williams
articles.snippet: Williams shareholders will vote on the merger soon, and on Monday the two companies will go to court to accuse each other of breaching the agreement.
articles.abstract: Williams shareholders will vote on the merger soon, and on Monday the two companies will go to court to accuse each other of breaching the agreement.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Kelcy L. Warren, the chief executive of the pipeline giant Energy Transfer Equity, cast a long shadow even among the Texas wildcatting elite, with a personal fortune estimated at more than $7 billion.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Leslie Picker

articles.headline: Mike Allen, Politico’s Newsletter Pioneer, Is Handing Over the Reins
articles.snippet: Mr. Allen’s Morning Playbook column influences many in Washington and beyond, but now he’s moving on — mid-election, at that — to a new project, leaving his legacy to be refreshed by the new guard.
articles.abstract: Mr. Allen’s Morning Playbook column influences many in Washington and beyond, but now he’s moving on — mid-election, at that — to a new project, leaving his legacy to be refreshed by the new guard.
articles.lead_paragraph: SIREN: WASHINGTON TO LOSE ITS DAILY BARD AT A MOST UNCERTAIN TIME: MIKE ALLEN WILL STOP WRITING POLITICO’S MORNING PLAYBOOK COLUMN MIDCAMPAIGN, on July 11 — A Guide to Capital Intrigue Through Entire Obama Era and Part of W. Bush’s — MILLENNIAL TAKEOVER: Politico Young Guns ANNA PALMER, JAKE SHERMAN and DANIEL LIPPMAN Grab the Baton — CHANGES IN STORE FOR A NEW ENVIRONMENT — Times Subscription Deal: 50 percent off for a year!

articles.headline: What Donald Trump Learned From Joseph McCarthy’s Right-Hand Man
articles.snippet: Roy Cohn, the Red-baiting Senate adviser and fearsome lawyer, counseled a young Mr. Trump for many years, nurturing a style of bluster and smears.
articles.abstract: Roy Cohn, the Red-baiting Senate adviser and fearsome lawyer, counseled a young Mr. Trump for many years, nurturing a style of bluster and smears.
articles.lead_paragraph: The future Mrs. Donald J. Trump was puzzled.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Mahler and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: China Wins New Bragging Rights in Supercomputers
articles.snippet: China has the largest number of computers among the top 500 — a first for any country other than the United States.
articles.abstract: China has the largest number of computers among the top 500 — a first for any country other than the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A new list of the world’s fastest supercomputers provides more evidence that the once-yawning technology gap between the United States and China is closing.

articles.headline: Martin Winterkorn, Ex-C.E.O. of Volkswagen, Is Under Investigation
articles.snippet: Mr. Winterkorn, who resigned in September, is the first member of the carmaker’s top management to be identified as a suspect in the emissions scandal.
articles.abstract: Mr. Winterkorn, who resigned in September, is the first member of the carmaker’s top management to be identified as a suspect in the emissions scandal.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The investigation into Volkswagen’s emissions scandal has for the first time reached the top echelon of management, threatening to undermine the company’s claim that wrongdoing was limited to a handful of lower-ranking managers and potentially increasing the already enormous financial damage.

articles.headline: Orlando Police Defend Actions as Clock Ticked in Massacre
articles.snippet: As partial transcripts of phone calls by the killer, Omar Mateen, were released, officials withstood lingering questions about the timing of the assault against him and whether police gunfire hit any victims.
articles.abstract: As partial transcripts of phone calls by the killer, Omar Mateen, were released, officials withstood lingering questions about the timing of the assault against him and whether police gunfire hit any victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some details of the Orlando nightclub massacre are known to the minute: The first reports of gunfire came at 2:02 a.m. The gunman made a 911 call at 2:35 a.m., in which he pledged allegiance to the Islamic State. By 5:15 a.m., as hostages fled to safety, he lay dead or mortally wounded in a scene of unimaginable carnage.
articles.byline: By Richard Pérez-Peña, Frances Robles and Eric Lichtblau
